UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

UnitType.Description: The Galadwenn are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance. The claim to trace their ancestry to air spirits and though that is unlikely, their grace is amazing.
UnitType.Backstory: These are the archers of Pariden, Amarians who are masters of the bow, trained in the same manner and using the same drills as the Ninety-Nine of Redstone. And no wonder - for their namesake, Galadwenn of the Free Cities, was himself heir to the Bow of Ydrain, said to have been used by Argynn in his war against the tribes of the Khulan.

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory:
You sealed yourself within the buried city of Calebethon, and toiled as each light went out. As the darkness crept through Calebethon there was a rising tide of screams and madness. It would be unjust to say that the citizens became as animals, because animals were never so cruel or afraid.
Eventually the darkness claimed those voices too, and the city settled to the gentle sounds of ragged breath and the drip of blood, flesh and filth. When the last light of Calebethon finally went out you could only hear echoes of your great city in the darkness. You have no memories of those last, horrible days.
When you awoke you walked through the streets of ancient Calebethon, and where you walked the long dead citizens of your city rose to follow.

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: Dross Archers are lightly equipped and count on numbers to kill their opponents. The Quendar believe that a bow makes one an archer, and they are quick to hand them out to untrained units when war requires.
UnitType.Backstory: Ages ago, when the legions of Antheros fell to the Quendar, Magnar II enslaved the soldiers of that once-great nation, forcing them to serve in the advance guard of his army. Since that day, the Quendar have made it a practice to not only enslave the conquered masses of their foes, but to forcibly 'enlist' them as foot soldiers. They are little more than cannon fodder, if truth be told - fed, clothed, and armed with the most meager essentials.

UnitType.Description: The Clan of the Crow are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance. Among the archers of Elemental the Clan is the most reknown for their skill.
UnitType.Backstory: Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: Archers are lightly equipped and skilled at picking off their opponents at a distance.
UnitType.Backstory: Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: Crossbowmen can fire through units in lines and are a great way to deal with masses of enemy units.
UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

UnitType.Description: Crossbowmen can fire through units in lines and are a great way to deal with masses of enemy units.
UnitType.Backstory: All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

When the last light of Calebethon finally went out you could only hear echoes of your great city in the darkness. You have no memories of those last, horrible days.

UnitType.Description: Destiny's Guard are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage. The Destiny's Guard is often hired out to protect artifacts and magical locations.

UnitType.Description: The Shields of Gilden are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage. They are well trained guardians and armies that include them will benefit from their protection.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: The Unfalling Legion are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage. They are well trained guardians and armies that include them will benefit from their protection.
UnitType.Backstory:
These are the elite soldiers of the Krax army, who receive both their training and their unit names in the citadel of the Warrior, in the heart of Tanacabra. According to Janusk of Krandir, those youths who enter the citadel break off all contact with their families, change their names, and pledge their lives to the service of the Emperor Karavox.
According to Karavox's ambassadors, none of that is true.

UnitType.Description: Defenders are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: Defenders are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage.
UnitType.Backstory: Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

UnitType.Description: The Sentinels of Hagudst are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage. Their decades of experience guarding some of the darkest places of Elemental has granted them a somber view of the world.
UnitType.Backstory: These are the eyes of the Enchantress; those fighters charged as Resoln's first line of defense against invaders. According to Gradzh of Hedigah, sole survivor of Kraxis's failed attempt to seize the city of Maz Galuur in the south of that country, these sentinels have been bewitched; their lifespans shortened by half, in order that they may serve without the need for sleep.

UnitType.Description: Barons are powerful melee units, able to do lots of damage to those that fall within their range.

UnitType.Description: Harbingers of War are powerful melee units, able to do lots of damage to those that fall within their range. They are the most elite of the Trog armies and not many can withstand their attacks.
UnitType.Backstory:
"The sound of their boots upon the city's cobblestones shall haunt my dreams, in this life and the next." - Hengut the Younger of Odenvell.
Trog heavy infantry. The armies of the Titans of old - the endless swarms of soldiers depicted in the great paintings and murals recovered from Imperium's ruins - were often led by units similar to these, whose appearance foretold the coming of battle, of death and destruction.

UnitType.Description: Barons are powerful melee units, able to do lots of damage to those that fall within their range.

As compared to other faction's horsemen the Knights are known for their speed and are often able to sweep over enemy spellcasters and archers before they have a chance to act.

This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: Warg riders are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: Ages ago, when the legions of Antheros fell to the Quendar, Magnar II enslaved the soldiers of that once-great nation, forcing them to serve in the advance guard of his army. Since that day, the Quendar have made it a practice to not only enslave the conquered masses of their foes, but to forcibly 'enlist' them as foot soldiers. They are little more than cannon fodder, if truth be told - fed, clothed, and armed with the most meager essentials.

UnitType.Description: Horsemen are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

UnitType.Description: Warg riders are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas.
UnitType.Backstory: These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

UnitType.Description: The Marrowguard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas. They are driven into a frenzy at the smell of blood and many commanders use archers to direct their attacks.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: The Tide of Teeth are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas. The Tide is known for nipping at the heels of powerful enemies. The tactic is frequently suicide, but unquestioningly effective.
UnitType.Backstory:
"Now you are the whirlwind; warg and rider, one flesh from two. Reap me a harvest of bright, red blood." - The Enchantress
These are mounted units of the Wraith army; warriors upon wargs, whose unearthly speed and savage ferocity have given rise to rumors of cannibalism upon the battliefield.

UnitType.Description: The Redwatch are good early skirmishers, quick to train and good in most battles. They learn faster than other faction's warriors and can become experienced units after only a few battles.
UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

UnitType.Description: Disciples are good early skirmishers, quick to train and good in most battles.
UnitType.Backstory: All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Description: Horned Axemen are good early skirmishers, quick to train and good in most battles.
UnitType.Backstory:
You sealed yourself within the buried city of Calebethon, and toiled as each light went out. As the darkness crept through Calebethon there was a rising tide of screams and madness. It would be unjust to say that the citizens became as animals, because animals were never so cruel or afraid.
Eventually the darkness claimed those voices too, and the city settled to the gentle sounds of ragged breath and the drip of blood, flesh and filth. When the last light of Calebethon finally went out you could only hear echoes of your great city in the darkness. You have no memories of those last, horrible days.
When you awoke you walked through the streets of ancient Calebethon, and where you walked the long dead citizens of your city rose to follow.

UnitType.Description: Warriors are good early skirmishers, quick to train and good in most battles.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: Axeman are good early skirmishers, though they can't wield shields their Cleave ability allows them to attack multiple enemies at once.
UnitType.Backstory: There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

UnitType.Description: Axeman are good early skirmishers, though they can't wield shields their Cleave ability allows them to attack multiple enemies at once.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: Axeman are good early skirmishers, though they can't wield shields their Cleave ability allows them to attack multiple enemies at once.
UnitType.Backstory: Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

UnitType.Description: Firebrands are good early skirmishers, quick to train and good in most battles. Key in the Tarth revolt the Firebrands still enjoy fighting against that are more powerful than they are.

UnitType.Description: Carrion Men are good early skirmishers, quick to train and good in most battles. Although dangerous from the start they are even more dangerous when injured, often flying into a berserk rage.

There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. UnitType.Backstory: Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: Gravewardens are mages that draw the lives from those they kill, adding it to their faction's mana.
UnitType.Backstory:
"Take pleasure in the killing, for it is what you were made to do." - The Enchantress
These are Wraith sorcerers trained in the arts of war; mages who share the Enchantress's blood, and thus, a bit of her power.

UnitType.Description: The Cinderwatch specializes is quick darting attacks. They can fire lethal volleys of flaming arrows at enemies and then be gone, taunting enemies to try to follow where they will receive another rain of fire.

Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

UnitType.Description: Most never experience more than the myth of the Cinereal Legion. Tales of black hooves and nightmarish charges through enemies like a scythe through wheat. The truth is even more gruesome.
UnitType.Backstory: These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. UnitType.Description: Witches are powerful ranged attackers with high mobility. Easily able to skirt around slower units and wear them down. Even worse, once the witch kills a victim that opponents life is collected as mana.
UnitType.Backstory: These sorcerers are the stuff of nightmares; Wraith enchantresses, bonded by sorcery to warg mounts. They were the first wave of Ceresa's creatures to attack Goyarh Hedigah, and after the city fell, they were said to have rended the Tazzar's body limb from limb, and carried it back to the caves of Gamush Ked to feast upon his brains and blood.

UnitType.Description: The Chosen are outfitted with enchanted weapons and items. They are a powerful tool for any empire, but expensive to train.

UnitType.Backstory: "I seek no mercenaries; the Silver Swordsmen and their ilk are unwelcome in the ranks of my army. What I seek are heroes - those who wish to make bettering this world their life's adventure!" These words - uttered at the nadir of the Nobles Revolt, when the armies of Procipinee surrounded Relias and his companions at the foot of Mount Essa - remain the rallying cry for all Altar's soldiers. This is an army of adventurers - many of whom are famous in their own right for the quests they have completed - an army that will sometimes dare the impossible and often achieve it.

UnitType.Description: Magebane are good midgame units for your armies. Unlike other faction's soldiers the Magebane receive training in fighting spell casters, and resisting their spells.
UnitType.Backstory: All who wear the colors of this army, from commander to common foot-soldier, can trace their lineage back to the great kingdoms of the pre-cataclysmic era - to Coriopolis, Zad-Zabril, and even fabled Antheros. The blood of the channelers of old runs in their veins; they know and are unafraid of using this power to aid them in combat, both as shield and sword, in defense and attack. The commander who would engage this army in battle most possess a similar familiarity with the enchanter's art.

UnitType.Description: Fallen Swordsmen are good midgame units for your armies.
UnitType.Backstory:
You sealed yourself within the buried city of Calebethon, and toiled as each light went out. As the darkness crept through Calebethon there was a rising tide of screams and madness. It would be unjust to say that the citizens became as animals, because animals were never so cruel or afraid.
Eventually the darkness claimed those voices too, and the city settled to the gentle sounds of ragged breath and the drip of blood, flesh and filth. When the last light of Calebethon finally went out you could only hear echoes of your great city in the darkness. You have no memories of those last, horrible days.
When you awoke you walked through the streets of ancient Calebethon, and where you walked the long dead citizens of your city rose to follow.

UnitType.Description: The Drolgard are armed with the pride of the Ironeer's, the Battle Hammer.
UnitType.Backstory: These are miners by trade; they make cautious soldiers, content to assess a battle's progress from a fortified position, to rely less on tactical skill and more on superior equipment to provide them advantage. Many among them are innately resistant to the channeler's basic spells, a trait inherited from the greatest of their kind, Fierann Ma Tua of the Aivernach.

UnitType.Description: Karavox's Honorguard are good midgame units for your armies. They are known for their resilience and stubborn refusal to retreat their position.
UnitType.Backstory: There are no more stalwart defenders than the armies of Kraxis; their ability to establish and protect near-unassailable battlefield positions is well-documented. Recall the siege of Morrania, the last of the great pre-cataclysmic battles between Man and Fallen, where four hundred Krax held off two thousand D'Rog fighters. Some may call them traitors, but the Krax have an unshakable belief in the righteousness of their cause, and an uncanny ability to persuade others to their side... a trait opposing commanders would do well to take note of.

UnitType.Description: Silver Swordsmen are good midgame units for your armies. Although they are more expensive than other faction's soldiers, not one questions their effectiveness.
UnitType.Backstory: The armies of Capitar have at their disposal the vast wealth of the great trading houses of old, money that lets them buy not just the best equipment, but the best fighters: mercenaries such as the Silver Swordsmen; archers whose skills rival the ninety-nine of Redstone; war horses bred from the stock of fabled Antheros. This great wealth buys influence in diplomatic councils as well as on the battlefield; a fact the seasoned commander would do well to keep in mind when forging alliances.

UnitType.Description: The Scourge are good midgame units for your armies. Although they aren't as well trained as other faction's soldiers they can be trained quickly and overwhelm the enemy.
UnitType.Backstory: These are the enslaved legions of the Quendar army - those captured citizens and soldiers forcibly enlisted to fight for the Quendar army. In the time before this one, they were fodder for Magnar's generals, sent forth as chess pawns to ferret out the enemy's strength and strategy. The scourge have a reputation as desperate, savage fighters - they fight only with survival in mind.

UnitType.Description: The Oak Guard are good midgame units for your armies. The Tarth equip these units with Throwing Knives, allowing them to deal some damage even before closing for melee combat.
UnitType.Backstory:
At the entrance to the great Arena in Capitar, there stood a mighty oak tree, from whose branches the heads of those gladiators killed in the Arena were often hung. When the rebellion began, Tarth led his closest companions to that tree, and from it cut down the remnants of those who had been his brothers. In their place, he hung the heads of the nobles and their ladies who had made sport of death.
The oak remains a potent symbol to the fighters of Tarth, whose soldiers wear its emblem as a reminder of the ties that bind them to one another.

UnitType.Description: The Battleborn are good midgame units for your armies. Do not mistake them for the lumbering brutes they appear to be, their training is extensive and prepares them well for battle.
UnitType.Backstory:
"I am father to a thousand children; to hearts that never falter, to limbs that never tire, to battlelust that is never quenched!" - The Warlord Verga
These are soldiers of the Trog army; Fallen creatures fashioned in the depths of N'it'vaganesh for one purpose only... war.

UnitType.Description: Swordsmen are great midgame units. Their swords leave a hand free for a shield and their counterattack ability allows them to strike back at enemies that attack them.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: Swordsmen are great midgame units. Their swords leave a hand free for a shield and their counterattack ability allows them to strike back at enemies that attack them.
UnitType.Backstory: Resoln is a new country - but its fighters draw their strength from the old powers, from the magics of the Dread Lord Curgen, most powerful of all the Titans to ever walk upon Elemental. The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: A peasant armed with a crude club.
UnitType.Backstory: Once they were rebels; slaves fighting to shake off the chains of the Capitaran arenas. Now they are an army - brave and determined soldiers with a country of their own to defend. Yet by training and nature Tarthans remain gladiators - used to fighting alone, or in small groups. They will strike quickly, and retreat, never allowing themselves to get bogged down in a long, drawn-out conflict. Their commanders drill them constantly on all types of terrain, so that in combat they may move as quickly in swamp as on packed earth.

UnitType.Description: A peasant armed with a crude club.
UnitType.Backstory: These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

The armies of Resoln discount the use of much equipment the typical soldier relies upon, and instead make use of the enchantments, spells, and creatures that are their birthright.

UnitType.Description: A peasant armed with a crude club.
UnitType.Backstory: Ages ago, when the legions of Antheros fell to the Quendar, Magnar II enslaved the soldiers of that once-great nation, forcing them to serve in the advance guard of his army. Since that day, the Quendar have made it a practice to not only enslave the conquered masses of their foes, but to forcibly 'enlist' them as foot soldiers. They are little more than cannon fodder, if truth be told - fed, clothed, and armed with the most meager essentials.

UnitType.Description: Use Explorers to explore the world. Altar Explorers take longer to train but they last longer than the scouts of other factions.

They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. UnitType.Description: The Gray March are effective against well armored enemies. They are stronger than other faction's spearmen and are drawn from the largest of the Trog.
UnitType.Backstory:
"It is a sea of lances I spy in the morning fog; a formation that comes ever, ever closer. I fear for our army, my love; I fear for our country, and yes, I fear for my own life as well." - Duc Lonte, 13th Baron of Ithul, writing to his wife as he prepared to battle the assembled armies of Sodesh Jushi, warlord of the Trogs.
The Gray March are the spearmen of the Trog (D'Rog) army; though they often form the front line of defense, these soldiers are not content to merely await attack, but will often be found initiating it.

UnitType.Description: Najaborn are effective against well armored enemies and coat their weapons in poison.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: Defenders are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage.
UnitType.Backstory: These are a primitive and violent people, said by some to be a sub-race of the Fallen, shaped by Curgen in those same years in which the Urxen were first formed. Cave dwellers by nature, the Cataclysm destroyed many of the darklings' original habitats, forcing them to take up a quasi-nomadic way of life. They are dangerous - thieves and killers by nature - and are to be avoided whenever possible, though it is rumored that given the proper incentive, they will form alliances of a sort.

UnitType.Description: Defenders are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage.
UnitType.Backstory: It's unknown whether those demons are from N'it'Vaganesh or from somewhere else. Rumor has it that they were once of the same race as the Titans but that their essence was drained from them for dark purposes. Anyhow, all that is known for certain is they draw their strength from devouring the life-force of other beings.

UnitType.Description: Defenders are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage.
UnitType.Backstory: Discipline is first, second, and third when building an effective fighting force. Little else matters.' These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

UnitType.Description: Defenders are formidable troops that are able to outlast enemy units and absorb lots of damage.
UnitType.Backstory: These are Elemental's most fearsome warriors; bred for battle, taught to strike without mercy and to ignore pain, to banish the words 'caution' and 'surrender' from their vocabulary. Whether you engage them in single combat, or fight them in phalanxes, you will learn the truth of those words attributed to Iskahar, last of Ereog's line, as he lay dying on the steppes of Engar. "It is no shame to perish to a superior foe."

UnitType.Description: Harbingers of War are powerful melee units, able to do lots of damage to those that fall within their range. They are the most elite of the Trog armies and not many can withstand their attacks.
UnitType.Backstory:
"The sound of their boots upon the city's cobblestones shall haunt my dreams, in this life and the next." - Hengut the Younger of Odenvell.
Trog heavy infantry. The armies of the Titans of old - the endless swarms of soldiers depicted in the great paintings and murals recovered from Imperium's ruins - were often led by units similar to these, whose appearance foretold the coming of battle, of death and destruction.

UnitType.Description: Barons are powerful melee units, able to do lots of damage to those that fall within their range.

UnitType.Description: The Marrowguard are excellent for scouting out unknown areas, and escaping when they uncover dangers in those areas. They are driven into a frenzy at the smell of blood and many commanders use archers to direct their attacks.

UnitType.Description: Carrion Men are good early skirmishers, quick to train and good in most battles. Although dangerous from the start they are even more dangerous when injured, often flying into a berserk rage.

UnitType.Description: Most never experience more than the myth of the Cinereal Legion. Tales of black hooves and nightmarish charges through enemies like a scythe through wheat. The truth is even more gruesome.

UnitType.Description: The Brood of Calebethon are feared through Umber and beyond. They are outfitted with the best items the enchanters and poisoners of Umber can produce.

UnitType.Description: The Battleborn are good midgame units for your armies. Do not mistake them for the lumbering brutes they appear to be, their training is extensive and prepares them well for battle.
UnitType.Backstory:
"I am father to a thousand children; to hearts that never falter, to limbs that never tire, to battlelust that is never quenched!" - The Warlord Verga
These are soldiers of the Trog army; Fallen creatures fashioned in the depths of N'it'vaganesh for one purpose only... war.

UnitType.Description: Swordsmen are great midgame units. Their swords leave a hand free for a shield and their counterattack ability allows them to strike back at enemies that attack them.

UnitType.Description: A peasant armed with a crude club.
UnitType.Backstory: Ages ago, when the legions of Antheros fell to the Quendar, Magnar II enslaved the soldiers of that once-great nation, forcing them to serve in the advance guard of his army. Since that day, the Quendar have made it a practice to not only enslave the conquered masses of their foes, but to forcibly 'enlist' them as foot soldiers. They are little more than cannon fodder, if truth be told - fed, clothed, and armed with the most meager essentials.

These words - spoken by Vergaxa of the Quendar - remain the watchword for the commanders of this army. They will make slaves of any fighter they defeat in battle; they will conscript any banker, baker, or miner whose path they cross. From those slaves they will make soldiers, and from those soldiers, massive armies driven by fear of the lash, and inculcated with the discipline prescribed by Vergaxa centuries earlier.

UnitType.Description: The Gray March are effective against well armored enemies. They are stronger than other faction's spearmen and are drawn from the largest of the Trog.
UnitType.Backstory:
"It is a sea of lances I spy in the morning fog; a formation that comes ever, ever closer. I fear for our army, my love; I fear for our country, and yes, I fear for my own life as well." - Duc Lonte, 13th Baron of Ithul, writing to his wife as he prepared to battle the assembled armies of Sodesh Jushi, warlord of the Trogs.
The Gray March are the spearmen of the Trog (D'Rog) army; though they often form the front line of defense, these soldiers are not content to merely await attack, but will often be found initiating it.

UnitType.Description: Najaborn are effective against well armored enemies and coat their weapons in poison.
UnitType.Backstory: For a thousand years, following their banishment from Imperium, the Urxen roamed the great Umbran wastes. There, in the shadow of the mountain ranges ruled by the Titan Ilosa, she who became the Lady Umber, they forged a special relationship with the creatures of Elemental, a bond that not even the Cataclysm could break. Even now, the Urxen can call to their cause the great serpents of this world - the naja and the ophidian - and command them in battle.

UnitType.Description: Spearmen are effective against well armored enemies.
UnitType.Backstory: These are a primitive and crude people. Often cave dwellers, they are short of stature and violent in nature. In Amarian's journey west, as told by Ezmir, these are called by the scribe a sub-race of Fallen, which may or may not be true.
